Similar items are to be provided or made for the autumnal rite as well. 〈Transporters are to be requested at the time from the [Royal Household] Ministry.〉
div.note: The Kasuga Spring Rite was conducted for the tutelary deity of the Fujiwara, the Kasuga Deity, in the second month in Sōnokami District, in what is now the northern end of Nara Prefecture. In the days prior to the rite, Palace Kitchen Office officials ordered cooks, menial laborers, and serving women to come to prepare foods and other offerings.

Plain-weave silk, or
ashiginu
, appears throughout the Engi Protocols. This term refers to a general category of a plain-weave silk textile made of a thicker thread.

Chōfu
tax cloth was a tax paid in kind item.

Outer robes made of hemp cloth, or
hitoeginu
, would be worn atop one's robes.

A train was fabric attached at the waist to trail behind the wearer. The female servants (
nyotei
,
jochō
女丁) were commoner women who performed a variety of tasks around the palace. These female servants came to work from different provinces.

Shōfu
, also read as
tani
, refers to a hemp cloth given as payment or tribute that could be exchanged for other goods.

div.p: The Ōharano Rite: this is the same as the Kasuga Rite.
div.note: The Ōharano Rite was held in the second month and eleventh month for the kami enshrined in Kyoto to protect the capital. When the capital was moved from Nara to Nagaoka in 784, the tutelary deity of the Fujiwara was made a protective deity of the new capital and palace, and when the capital was moved again to Kyoto in 794, it was enshrined as the protective deity of Kyoto.

div.p:
The Tsukihi Spring Rite: 2 high tables 〈to be provided by the Carpentry Bureau〉, 4 pieces of
chōfu
tax cloth 〈each piece to be 5
shaku
in length and large enough to spread beneath the table〉, 8
Sue pottery
tall dishes
, 2 [Sue pottery] rounded square jars, 2 wooden rice containers, 1
kin
of mulberry floss. 〈These are to be prepared by the Palace Storehouse Bureau.〉 The
female chamberlains (
naishi
)
are to request the various items above. As for the items being offered to the kami, the ingredients are to be taken out of the monthly provisions and prepared, arranged on the high tables, and sent to the Wardrobe Bureau. Similar items are to be provided or made for the autumnal rite as well.
div.note: Sue pottery is a type of stoneware fired above 1000°C, yielding a strong, gray pottery. Sue is unglazed, except for ashes that melt against its surface. Sue contrasts with another pottery type, Haji, which was unglazed and fired at a lower temperature. Both pottery types were regarded as utilitarian. The square jars mentioned here were a pottery made in Mino and Bizen provinces.

These tall dishes, or
takasara
, were bowls attached to stands that made them taller than other pottery dishes. A single “leg” mounted in the center supported the bowl.
Female chamberlains worked in the Back Palace serving the sovereign by conveying royal commands, managing lower level servants, and generally keeping things running.

div.note:
These were kami worshipped by the Royal Household Ministry. In this case, a rite was conducted specifically for the
sono
kami, or garden deities, that provided food for the sovereign.
The Keihoku and Naki Gardens are specifically named gardens, whereas Nagaoka, Nara, Yamashina, and Hatsukashi are places that contained gardens with kami to be worshipped for helping to provide food.

This ranking system used for the kami was the one used for officials, and there was a substantial difference between the fifth and sixth ranks. The sixth rank was a common for officials involved in government administration. This fifth ranking kami of the Capital's Northern Garden occupied a more important position in the ceremony than the sixth rankers.

Mixed-color barkcloth, or
shizu
, was made of paper mulberry, hemp, or other fibers woven in an irregular mix of colors.

Fermented fish was a precursor to what a modern reader would identify as sushi. It is made by cleaning a fish, salting it, and then packing the fish with cooked rice whereupon it undergoes a lactic acid fermentation process. Lactic acid bacteria and acetic bacteria transform the fish into a pungent, sour product.
This is a type of tax cloth that was originally paid in instead of corvée labor.

div.note: The Hirano Rite was conducted for the kami of Hirano Shrine, which protected the maternal line of Kanmu Tennō, the royal house, and in particular, the crown prince. They also were tutelary deities of the Minamoto and Taira. The Four Seasons' Rites protocols lists four kami associated with Hirano Shrine.

This occurs during the night of the Tsukinami Rite, which was done in the sixth and twelfth months. For the Tsukinami Rite, officials of government and shrines gathered for the reading of
norito
prayers followed by alms. These ingredients listed here would be consumed during the night as the sovereign communed with the kami.

Azuma abalone refers to abalone produced in the eastern provinces in a particular manner. Kiyotake Yūji points out that Azuma abalone specifically came from Awa Province, as well as Kazusa Province, so it was not simply “abalone of the east,” which encompassed a wider territory for “eastern” goods, but a specific regional preparation.

While there are no contemporary directions for making this preparation, the characters used here give us a hint. This
ayu
, or sweetfish, was liked boiled in saltwater to help preserve it.

Hishio
was a fermented product made from grain and soybeans, similar to miso. The Banquet Protocols has an ingredient list for
hishio
: soybeans, rice (for inculcating, likely with kōji spores), glutinous rice, adzuki beans, sake, and salt. This was one of the four condiments, or
shishu mono
, served at banquets.

This is referring specifically to
kachiguri
, a chestnut preparation that consists of pounding dried chestnuts and removing the bitter skin.

Hotogi
jars were a deep jar with a wide mouth. They could be made of earthenware, such as the ones sent from Yamato, Bizen, and Sanuki, which are recorded in the Accounting Bureau protocols (
Shukei
主計). Arai Hideki has proposed that earthenware
hotogi
jars were used for keeping things warm, while the sturdier Sue types would be used for transporting goods and storage.

A
chihaya
was a type of jacket or outer robe worn by workers. The cloth was made of hemp and bleached by sun exposure to become white.
